results.title: Sea power
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description: The aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne and the Oberon class submarine HMAS Otway take part in an exercise off the eastern coast of Australia. Also seen are the destroyer HMAS Hobart, the supply ship HMAS Stalwart, minesweepers, Navy oil tankers, patrol boats, and some of the Navy’s aircraft.

results.title: Sea area: Forties
results.creator_credit: John Armstrong, British Petroleum and Pelican Films
results.brief_description: The exciting story of how the sponsors developed their Forties Field in the North Sea and were the first to bring oil ashore in quantity. The film also shows how BP have endeavoured to respect the surrounding countryside and the wishes and well-being of local people.

results.title: Sculpture: the forms of life
results.creator_credit: Brooke M. Beebe, Ted Lowry and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Various techniques of sculpture as well as a wide variety of sculptures from all cultures and times show how it reflects the spirit of these eras through the vision of the sculptor. The changing nature of sculpture is shown through demonstrations of varying techniques, styles and functions of this three dimensional art.

results.title: Sculpture: process of discovery
results.brief_description: As sculptor Norm Hines searches for the shape he says is hidden in a rock, he discusses his approach to creativity. He has no preconceived form - the shape is decided as it happens.

results.title: Seaweeds
results.creator_credit: Grant Crabtree and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A fascinating, informative report of marine agronomy as it is being developed on Canada’s Atlantic coast. The film shows the work of the National Research Council’s Atlantic Regional Laboratory at Halifax and of Constance MacFarlane, marine botanist of the Nova Scotia Research Foundation. Efforts are directed at developing the food potentials of marine plants such as dulse, Irish moss, rockweed.

results.title: Seaweed walk
results.creator_credit: Barry Cowling, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A group of people take advantage of a unique program sponsored by the Nova Scotia Museum. Bus tours led by a botanist visit the seashore, where the visitors are encouraged to identify the many varieties of seaweed. The guide describes the biological characteristics and commercial uses of the marine plants.

results.title: Seaside searching
results.brief_description:
Seaside Searching consists of interviews with ‘traditional’ local residents about St Kilda and surrounds and how the area is changing, in the context of 100 years history. Speakers include working girls, homeless, welfare workers, and aboriginal residents. While the technical quality is not great, vision and sound are clear.
At first the viewer is not sure where the journey is going, and whether the speakers’ words will be enough to hold our attention given the relative lack of visual stimulation. However as the program continues we are drawn in and held by the honesty, openness and truth of what we hear. The exterior interview locations grow on the viewer as markers of place. We realise that these uneducated or unsophisticated voices are saying important and meaningful things about community, change, class and status, and how regional social change affects the individual. By the close, one likes and believes in these ‘ordinary people’, and learns the value of community voices irrespective of their apparent form.

results.title: Search goes full circle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Search”.
This episode of the British television series “Search” looks at recycling waste materials in order to be more environmentally aware. Shows how to compost, make recyled paper and discusses the recycling of items such as cans, and second hand clothing which is made into a felt-like material and used as filling

results.title: Search for the shark callers
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Maynard and Grainger Maynard
results.brief_description: A description of a two month trek by kayak through the Solomon Islands, showing the people and their culture, wildlife and tourist attractions. Experience the dying art of summon sharks with a native priest, visit steaming volcanoes and take part in pagan dances and other local ceremonies!
